DOC.HEAD: Bush to Propose Record Spending, Weighs User Fees
DOC.TEXT: President Bush worked Tuesday toward a final version of a 1991 budget plan that sources said would include a record $1.24 trillion in spending. Meanwhile, he signed a deficit-fighting bill trimming the budget for this year. Despite Bush's ``no new taxes'' vows, the new federal budget also is likely to propose a series of new excise taxes, including a fee on the sale of certain recreational equipment and vehicles, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater confirmed that the Office of Management and Budget was weighing such a levy, among other ``user fees.'' However, Fitzwater added, ``The budget is not final and the decisions have not been made in the final sense.'' Administration sources said the White House had tentatively decided to propose new excise taxes on such recreational gear and vehicles as camping equipment and off-road vehicles, to pay for conservation measures. Other sources said Bush has tentatively decided against a new excise tax on the sale of boats and recreational vehicles, even though an earlier budget-office draft contained such fees. Bush plans to resolve all outstanding issues on the new budget before he leaves town Friday for a ten-day Christmas vacation. The 1991 budget, for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1, goes to Congress on Jan. 22. Bush's signature on the $14.7 billion budget reconciliation bill closes the book on the 1990 budget _ with total spending put at just under $1.2 trillion _ and lifts an order that had imposed $16.2 billion in mandatory cuts last October. ``The across-the-board cuts imposed would have disrupted some important federal activities had they remained in effect all year,'' Bush said in signing the measure. Bush praised Congress for making the new cuts ``in a manner consistent with my pledge not to raise new taxes.'' In Congress, debate on the deficit-reduction package broke down into partisan wrangling as the White House sought unsuccessfully to use the measure as a vehicle for its bid for a lower capital gains tax. To accomplish the needed savings, the bill retains $4.6 billion of the across-the-board cuts and enacts $6 billion in new taxes and fees, mostly on corporations. It makes up the rest by trimming Medicare payments to doctors and hospitals, cutting some farm programs, stretching out payments in some federal retirement programs, and speeding up collections on payroll and gasoline taxes. As for the fiscal 1991 budget, while officials will not discuss it publicly, an outline is slowly taking shape that sources say will include: _Military spending of $292 billion, just $1 billion over the current level. Reduced world tensions are responsible for some of the defense slowdown, expected to be the smallest percentage increase in a decade. _No major new initiatives, but modest increases in some programs, including the environment, education, AIDS research, and anti-crime and drug efforts, generally reflecting many of Bush's first-year initiatives. _The abolition of some minor programs, but nothing like the proposed wholesale agency terminations unsuccessfully proposed by former President Reagan; cuts in Medicare funds and the proposed sale of some federal assets. _A renewal of Bush's campaign for a lower capital gains tax, a cut the administration sees as a big revenue-raiser. _A revival, in slightly different form, of Bush's 1988 campaign proposal under which Americans could save up to $5,000 a year in special tax-free ``family savings accounts'' for funds deposited 10 or more years. _An overhaul and consolidation of the government's credit programs, seeking to save tax dollars by streamlining bookkeeping on a wide range of government loans. The administration must come up with some $40 billion in deficit savings in a mix of spending cuts and revenue increases to get the budget deficit down _ on paper at least _ to the $64 billion deficit target in the Gramm-Rudman budget balancing law for fiscal 1991. The target for fiscal 1989 was $100 billion. The budget-writing chore is being made easier this year by Bush's decision to keep the increase in defense spending down, and by a still healthy economy, now in its eighth year of recovery with inflation holding steady at a moderate 4 percent to 5 percent.
